I'm an aspiring science fiction writer and the type of science I would like to write is "hard sci-fi". That is, I want to create fantastic technologies that obey the laws of physics. I'm just trying to decide if teleportation is one of those things. Let's examine the two possibilities: quantum teleportation and matter/energy conversion.
 
 
 I read an article on the net about quantum physics and in one section, the author mentions about quantum teleportation. Here is a quote from the author:
 
 
 "Teleportation: As the probability wave suggests, you can get from Point A to Point C without necessarily passing through Point B. Small particles can jump from one location to another without actually moving through space between points, which is sometimes called a 'quantum leap'. In theory, this could be extended to larger particles."
 
 
 And here is the link:
 
 
 http://www.rotten.com/library/religion/quantum-physics/
 
 
 The aforementioned site is on quantum tunneling. Unfortunately, teleportation can only work for things at the microscopic level only, and not at the macroscopic stage. In the subatomic world, things are very fuzzy. The probability of a single electron tunneling even an inch is so improbable, that you may have to wait for the entire life of the universe and never see it happen anyway. 
 
 
 The probability of TWO particles tunneling from the same place to the same place at the same time is even lower. Now, the probability of all of the matter in your body tunneling even a micrometer in the same direction at the same time is, again, so improbable, you'll never see it happen. Its more probably that your head will tunnel a few feet away from the rest of your body. Can you imagine how morbidly amusing life would be if this weren't so improbable?
 
 
 To make this even worse, we have no control over this. In fact, we can't even predict when or how it will happen. Its not just an engineering nightmare, its a line in the rule book that the universe seems to adhere to. I guess that means we can scratch off quantum tunneling as a good candidate for teleporting people.
 
 
 1) Thoughts anyone?
 
 
 But then I thought of another possibility for teleportation: the conversion of matter into energy and vice-versa. Einstein has stated in his equations that matter and energy are interconvertible. An experiment at Stanford University was accomplished at S.L.A.C. (short for Stanford Linear Accelerator Center). Michael Pidwirny, the guy who wrote it claimed that it might one day be a useful means of teleportation like in Star Trek. Here is a direct quote from him:
 
 
 "In 1998 researchers at Stanford University's Linear Accelerator Center successfully converted energy into matter. This feat was accomplished by using lasers and incredibly strong electromagnetic fields to change ordinary light into matter. The results of this experiment may allow for the development of variety of technological gadgets. One such development could be matter/energy transporters or food replicators that are commonly seen in some of our favorite science fiction programs."
 
 
 Here is the website: 
 
 http://www.physicalgeography.net/fundamentals/6a.html
 
 
 Here are some links to SLAC's statements released to various publications concerning the experiment: 
 
 
 http://www.slac.stanford.edu/exp/e144/nytimes.html
 
 
 http://www.slac.stanford.edu/exp/e144/science1202.html
 
 
 Personally, I don't think that there will ever be a conventional use for converting energy into matter because of the amount of energy contained in one human being. Think about it: if one human can produce thousands of hiroshimas bombs, then you would need thousands of atom bombs worth of energy to create a turkey sandwich. That just doesn't seem practical to me. If that amount of energy were to be released when turning a man into energy, well let's just say there wouldn't be much left of anything for a few thousand miles! In any conversion of matter, some energy is inevitably lost. In addition, such conversions of particles to energy are called annihilations, that is, they are like explosions: the explosive material is completely destroyed and no memory of its original form remains. 
 
 
 Now imagine for the sake of arugment that there was a way around the second law of theromodynamics. Teleportation could be accomplish by converting a person into energy and you had the technology to reverse the process. In addition, you send the information along with the energy.
 
 
 The question is, would the person survive the procedure, or would the individual cease to exist and be replaced with a replica, who was literally born into existence once the energy was reconverted back into matter with the information? 
 
 
 In my view, when your body is converted into energy, you're destroy, hence, you die. End of story. What comes out of the teleporter is an exact copy, with all your memories etc, and no knowledge that it isn't you, but it isn't. No one would ever notice the problem, so it only affects you when it happens. Unless, if you believe in souls, there are "conservation of souls" problems to deal with - does the same soul follow the body around? While in an energy state, there is no consciousness, no heart to beat, hence the person who first underwent this form of teleportation has cease to exist and replaced with a replica. 
 
 
 2) What does everybody else thinks? (Note: I know this question sounds a bit philosophical but I'd be very interested in everyones' opinion anyway.) 
 
 
 There is another problem with the matter/energy conversion teleporter. The thing that always bothered me about this method of teleportation is that once a crew member is converted into energy, that energy is something akin to plasma. Meaning that that energy has to go somewhere. And the only way to get rid of it is to blast a hole in the ceiling for all the energy to escape before it destroys everyone on the ship! When Star Trek creator Gene Roddenberry created the transporter, he did so because he couldn't afford on his television budget to land a huge starship or shuttlecraft on a planet every week. So, the transporter was born. 
 
 
 In addition, he also invented Subspace, where once the crew member is converted into energy, it is sent through subspace, exits at it's appointed destination and the process is reversed. But in real life Subspace does not exist. That being said, if you convert a person into energy and you send it to its destination such as a building, the transmitted energy would not only punch a hole through the ceiling, it would also destroy the house and everything surrounding it. Therefore, I think it would be better to convert a person into a radio signal, that way it can pass through barriers like walls and ceilings without destroying them. 
 
 
 3) Any thoughts?
 
 
 Whitestar

post_info.post_title: Teleportation: An article on the conversion of energy into matter

I have yet to read all of it, but here's an idea,
 
 why don't we simply take a composite scan of a person, noting all of the atom's and electrons positions, send THAT to the location, and build the scan from atoms and eletrons there. Much easier then sending the originals.

First off, you should check out this site:
 http://www.philosophers.co.uk/games/identity.htm
 
 It's a philosophy site, and this "game" deals with various scenarios, including teleportation, where you have to choose the path most likely to gaurantee your survival. It fits in perfectly with your concerns.
 
 On to other matters. The problem with quantum tunneling, as I recall, isn't so much a matter of probability as of size. The larger a particle is, the less profound quantum effects are. Thus, and electron can tunnel a distance many times greater than its size, whereas you or I could only tunnel a distance a fraction the size of an electron. In other words, no real distance at all.
 
 As for "reading" a person's info, and then beaming the info, with or without the energy contained in their bodies, and reconstructing them, Heisenburg says no go. Heisenburg's Uncertainty Principal says that it's impossible to know the position and momentum of a particle to a given degree of accuracy at the same time. The greater the precision of one measurment, the worse the precision on the other. While you might be able to get enough info to recreate the general shape of someones body, things like memory would most likely be lost.
 
 In Star Trek, they dealt with this by having a "Heisenburg Compensator" as one of the transporter components.
 
 I think the best bet for travel which takes no time is worm holes. Granted, we've never actually seen one, but we have no certain knowledge that they're impossible either.

Kronus: True. We only know the probability of a particle at a certain moment, but that is a hella of a lot easier then figuring out how to convert matter to energy and energy to matter without a loss of either. 
 
 
things like memory would most likely be lost.

 
 Still, easier to fix then converting energy into matte.r

Kronus: True. We only know the probability of a particle at a certain moment, but that is a hella of a lot easier then figuring out how to convert matter to energy and energy to matter without a loss of either. 
 

 
 I don't think so. We know that energy and matter can be interchanged, doing so is just an engineering problem. However, the uncertainty principle is a basic law of the universe. There is no way, even in theory, to get around it. It is, as far as we know, an unsurmountable problem, as opposed to converting energy and matter, which is just really, really hard.

I don't think so. We know that energy and matter can be interchanged, doing so is just an engineering problem. However, the uncertainty principle is a basic law of the universe. There is no way, even in theory, to get around it. It is, as far as we know, an unsurmountable problem, as opposed to converting energy and matter, which is just really, really hard.

 
 You mean the most massive engineering problem the human race will probably face for the next 300 years? Okay, so we can't transfer memories due to chemical composition and what not, but we can reconstruct someone from atoms up, and then transfer memories from a computer to a direct neutral net. That HAS to be easier to figuring out and implenting widescale matter to energy-energy to matter constructs that have no loss of energy in the process. Transfering teryabits of information really isn't that hard.

You mean the most massive engineering problem the human race will probably face for the next 300 years?  You're missing the point. It not that transfering the info is hard, it's that reading the info is impossible. In order to read the personality, memories, etc of a person you'd need to know precisely the location and momentum of every electron in every neuron in the brain. That's not hard, it's impossible, according to everything we know about quantum mechanics.

You're missing the point. It not that transfering the info is hard, it's that reading the info is impossible. In order to read the personality, memories, etc of a person you'd need to know precisely the location and momentum of every electron in every neuron in the brain. That's not hard, it's impossible, according to everything we know about quantum mechanics.

 
 ...which is changing as we learn more and more. Science is not a fixed thing like religion (unless you're talking about basic chemistry, which hasn't changed in decades). To assume that science at this current moment says it will forever be impossible is laughable. But let's assume that for this moment, how the hell are we going to convert matter to energy, then energy to matter and recombine perfectly, without a loss of a single particle?

...which is changing as we learn more and more. Science is not a fixed thing like religion (unless you're talking about basic chemistry, which hasn't changed in decades). To assume that science at this current moment says it will forever be impossible is laughable. But let's assume that for this moment, how the hell are we going to convert matter to energy, then energy to matter and recombine perfectly, without a loss of a single particle?

 
 Who says you don't have to loose a single particle? Energy is energy. Disintegrate them on this end, send the energy wherever, and make up any losses by disintegrating some rocks and adding in that energy too. It's not like energy "remembers" that it used to be a toenail back when it was matter. For that matter (no pun) there's no need to disintegrate the person at all, unless the magical scanning technique is destructive. Just beam the info about how to build the person, and make them from scratch on the other end, converting whatever matter is handy into energy, and then back into matter. Of course, that means there are two of you now, but that's a seperate set of problems.

Who says you don't have to loose a single particle? Energy is energy.

 
 But no system of transfer is perfectly efficent. Every system has some loss of energy for some reasons we don't understand. Even superconductors at extremely low temperatures have signifcent amounts of waste energy. 
 
 
Disintegrate them on this end, send the energy wherever, and make up any losses by disintegrating some rocks and adding in that energy too. beam the info about how to build the person, and make them from scratch on the other end, converting whatever matter is handy into energy, and then back into matter.

 
 How does this get around the same problem of rebuilding a person without losing memories?

How does this get around the same problem of rebuilding a person without losing memories?

 
 That was, in fact, entirely my point. It doesn't, and there is no way that we know of. In order to teleport someone without losing memories you have to invent an entirely new science that gets around everything we know about quantum mechanics.

Who says you don't have to loose a single particle? Energy is energy. Disintegrate them on this end, send the energy wherever, and make up any losses by disintegrating some rocks and adding in that energy too. It's not like energy "remembers" that it used to be a toenail back when it was matter.

 
 
 Yes, you're right that whenever you convert matter into energy, some energy is inevitably lost due to entropy. The second law of thermodynamics clearly states this. However, you just mentioned that the energy loss could be compensated simply by converting some rocks into energy. Even if we could do so, do you believe that the person who first underwent the procedure would survive or would the individual be replaced with a replica?
 
 
 Whitestar

Even if we could do so, do you believe that the person who first underwent the procedure would survive or would the individual be replaced with a replica?
 
 Whitestar

 
 Yes, and yes.
 
 I believe that a person is the sum of their experiences. If you could make an exact duplicate of someone, down to the quantum level, so that that copy had all the same memories and personality, then the copy would be that person for all intents and purposes. The actual physical bits would be different, but I'm told that happens every 7 years anyway. This is the same thing, speeded up.

A Star Trek style teleporter would be one of the best dang inventions mankind could ever come up IMHO.
 
 I've wanted one for as long as I can remember, and now that I live seven hours from my family, I REALLY wish I had one.
 
 Waxy

That's why I drive a Ford pickup, when I arrive I'm not blowing a big hole in some poor guy's wall or ceiling. My brain is pretty much in the same state as when I left as far as the electrons and neurons go, except once I accidentally called my aunt Margaret instead of Martha. emoticon_smile 
 
 But still, teleportation is too out there, IMO. I prefer the vague hope of wormholes. If we can learn to access them they may provide the shortcuts we're looking for, plus we can remain in one (albeit smaller) piece.

IMHO, teleportation will NEVER HAPPEN! Not only will it never happen, it'll never come close to happening. (Neither will time travel.) The destruction of the entity to be transported will be the end of that entity.
 
 I'm sorta in agreement with billsco. If I want to go somewhere, I crank up the truck.

 Just like man would never fly? Just like man would never reach the abyss? Just like man would never talk to another person 5,000 miles away? Just like man would never reach the stars? Do you have strong religious beliefs that are the same as the Church? 
 
 Time travel is theotrical in terms of going forward, not backward.

Just like man would never fly? Just like man would never reach the abyss? Just like man would never talk to another person 5,000 miles away? Just like man would never reach the stars? Do you have strong religious beliefs that are the same as the Church?

I suppose that means that if you're ever able to go forward, you can't come back. Can you stand still and wait for everyone else to catch up?

Can you stand still and wait for everyone else to catch up?

 
 If you didn't have to do any of the necessary functions to stay alive, possibly, assuming that difference in the time you currently reside in and left isn't more then your life time.

 The main problem I see with teleportation is that my bags will still end up somewhere else.

 :) :)
 
 Regarding teleportation, my guess is the quantum issue will plague any sort of "scan", it will be a physical impossibility (not for lack of creativity, just not within the bounds of physics) to scan and recreate without changing the original.
 
 I'd be more satisfied with immortality and an autopilot. Switch me off...zip me 1000 light years away, turn me back on. Relatively speaking, I'm there instantly. 
 
 -Mach
Anheiser-Busch has invented a teleportation device. I saw it on TV just the other day. You reach through a smoking door and pull out a Bud Lite.

In order to do teleportation a la Star Trek you would need a computer at both ends capable of knowing the quantum state and position of every atom in your body and reproduce it exactly at the other end. Don't know if that would be you however, and not just a clone with your memories. Does the unique perspective transfer?
 
 Anyway quantum coupled teleportation would mean you would have to entangle every quanta in your body with a duplicate, but that would be a duplicate anyway...
 
 The only thing that entanglement is good for as I see it now would be to have instantanious communications. Perhaps then you could have clones stationed around the galazy and just upload a copy of yourself. Bang! Instant travel. Unless that is, your clone doesn't want to be reabsorbed into you after the trip is over.
If you were to fold space somehow as to step from one place to another.

If you were to fold space somehow as to step from one place to another.

 
 Wormholes are not the same thing as teleportation. In appearance they are similar, in that you travel distances in little to no time. Functionally they are very different, however. Teleportation does not require any sort of mucking with space-time, you "just" convert someone into energy, send the energy at the speed of light to its destination, and then "just" convert the energy back into a person. Wormholes require either bending space or finding a place where space is already bent, and then punching a couple of holes in space and connecting them with a tunnel. So really, not all that similar in fundemental principal.

 Have you ever seen the Outerlimits, the remade versions, there is an episode called "think like a dino" or "think like a dinosaur". This episode deals with trasporters. What the concept in the show is that people lay on this bed then they are completly covered with this substance and scanned then the information is then transfered and the orginal copy of you is then distroyed using high powered lazar. The twist in the show was that a transfer was incomplete and the person was allowed to get up out of the substance. Later in the show we find out that the transfer was actually completed and the orginal copy of the person had to be killed. 
 
 The point is that any transporter based on current physics would have to act this way creating cloned copies of yourself. Even in Star Trek there is an episode in which Richer is cloned in such a way.

The point is that any transporter based on current physics would have to act this way creating cloned copies of yourself. Even in Star Trek there is an episode in which Richer is cloned in such a way.
 Do you mean Ricker in the episode of TNG where the ship that beamed up William Ricker caused part of him to go back down to the ship he was on and became Thomas Ricker? Then the Enterprise picks up a distress signal a number of years later? What about the episode with Scotty, "Relic" or something like that? He placed his essence into the teleporter and several years later he was put back right by the Enterprise crew.
 
 
 My question to the idea of transporters is what about the movie "The Fly?" Jeff Goldblum transports himself from one pod to another. But what happened was that a fly got in the system and got put back to gether with him. Then the more this happened, the more of a bug he became. If anything transports with you, would they then become a part of you, or you a part of them?
 As far as the writing of Hard-Science Fiction, you can either do transporter or wormhole. The only real differnce is what you write about it. (I took a Sci-Fi Lit class.) If you put infacis on how they work and are put together or generized, then both can work.

 I do get the idea of were you are going. Think about it for a second some sort of energy force pulling you apart a atom at a time and then reassembling you at the other end. Sounds very painfull to me.

... (I took a Sci-Fi Lit class.)  If you put infacis on how they work and are put together or generized, then both can work.
Did the teacher put any emphasis on spelling?
 
 Did they teach you that fiction is the operative word? Just because something appears to be workable doesn't mean it will ever happen. Lost in Space is just a story.

Did they teach you that fiction is the operative word? Just because something appears to be workable doesn't mean it will ever happen. Lost in Space is just a story.

 For the record, even if it is fiction, there still has to be some concept of science and what we already know about science and the theories. This is what seperates Science-Fiction from fantasy and/or regular fiction. There is a science to worm-holes. What we don't know is if we could safely go through one or how they are put together. We know that we can split atoms but we don't know how to do that safely in a transporter. The intire point to science fiction is to tell a story with a point in an odd setting and with some times odd charicters and with odd devices that would not be workable in our time. If you tell a story with a point but there is nothing out of the ordinary, all you have is fiction. Now why do you disbelieve that anything in science-fiction stories could ever happen. We already know that we can go into space. We already know that we can break the sound barrier. Isn't it true that a while back in England, they were building a starship. What's wrong with a belief in the possibilities? The guy who started the thread originally was trying to write a novel and wanted to know what was already known. Granted, we will probibly only be able to travel to the future if we could time travel, but when you think about it, are we really living in a time that some one from the future would want to come here? For the record, most of Science Fiction takes place in the future to make up for the fact that you are not able to do some things.
 
 BTW, my Lit of Sci-Fi class was in college and they stoped giving spelling test in 8th grade.
